(Memorandum by the Minister of Labour).The question of the urgent need of taking steps to s.secure increased production is a matter to which I have for some time been giving earnest consideration, and i have come to the conclusion that the time has arrived when a public Enquiry ought to be held; i announced, therefore, in the House last Wednesday, in reply to a Question, that it was proposed to set up a Committee of Enquiry, I am now taking the necessary steps to carry out this declaration and I circulate for the information of my colleagues the following particulars.The Committee of Enquiry will consist of an independent Chairman and a "permanent" nucleus composed of two employers, two labour representatives, and two Government officials, together with additional representatives appointed, two by the employers and two by the workpeople, to represent any particular trade which may be under consideration by the Committee.. The trade representatives will leave the Committee when thjir particular trade is finished with and representatives of other trades will take their place.II am asking the Confederation of Employers' Organisations to nominate the two permanent employers, and the Parliamentary Committee of the Trades Union Congress to nominate two permanent labour representatives. The. two Government representatives p will be one from the - Ministry of Labour and one to represent i the Government Spending Departments, to be selected by agreement] among those Departments6I -1- 226I have asked Sir htephenson, Kent, who had great labour experience during the War at the Ministry of Munitions, to be the Chairman of the Committee.The terms of reference will be "to consider and advise as to the best means of securing the greatest possible production consistent with the permanent well being of industry and ofall those engaged in it".(Signed) R.S. HORNE.2nd March 1920c/
